story.full_text:
“The Green-Stone God and the Stockbroker” unfolds as a psychologically layered detective story examining the brutal murder of Mrs. Paul Vincent, intertwining themes of financial desperation, hidden passions, and cryptic symbolism. The narrative begins with the discovery of Mrs. Vincent’s corpse in the study of Ulster Lodge, a Brixton residence, evidencing a violent struggle and apparent robbery, notably the theft of two hundred pounds. Mr. Vincent, a stockbroker frequently away on business, had left his wife home alone that fateful evening, creating opportunity and suspicion alike.

The investigation, led by a thoughtful and pragmatic inspector, emphasizes the steady accumulation of factual evidence over romanticized genius. Initial clues include a broken fencing foil and a missing hatchet—objects that imply a close-quarters confrontation rather than random intrusion. The peculiar discovery of an enigmatic green-stone idol of presumed New Zealand origin beneath the fireplace becomes a central symbol with potential to unlock hidden motives.

Key to the unfolding mystery is Julian Roy, a medical student and acquaintance of Mr. Vincent, who had been in financial entanglements with the stockbroker and associated with Clara Ford, a woman whose brother was caught in embezzlement troubles. The stolen money traces a complicated web of debts and desperation, setting the stage for a financial motive behind the crime. The detective carefully maneuvers to trap the suspect, informing banks about the stolen notes and withholding information to avoid alerting the perpetrator prematurely, culminating in Roy’s arrest at his lodgings.

Roy’s defense is complex and emotionally charged: he claims he was at Ulster Lodge on Vincent’s instructions to collect a loan to assist Clara Ford’s brother, arguing that Vincent had authorized the release of money by Mrs. Vincent. He insists that upon leaving, Mrs. Vincent was unharmed and content. However, Mr. Vincent vehemently denies providing any such authorization, casting suspicion on Roy’s version of events. The detective, recognizing the intricacies of evidence and testimony, refrains from premature conclusion, though the public prematurely hails Roy’s arrest as a solution.

Enter Clara Ford, who passionately advocates for Roy’s innocence, revealing her engagement to him and denouncing Mr. Vincent as a duplicitous figure. She describes Vincent not as a devoted husband but as a man with dishonorable intentions toward her—having made improper proposals and attempted to disrupt her relationship with Roy. Clara’s revelations point to a darker portrait of Vincent; driven possibly by passion and deceit, he presents as a man who both coveted Clara and bore resentment toward Roy. She proposes to prove Vincent’s true character by orchestrating a confrontation, inviting the detective to witness Vincent’s duplicity firsthand in her brother’s rooms.

This segment significantly enriches the narrative, shifting suspicion and complicating motives. Clara’s courage and sharpness contrast with the detective’s methodical approach, introducing the potent element of personal betrayal and hidden emotional currents within the circle around Vincent and Roy. She expresses firm belief in Roy’s innocence despite overwhelming appearances, appealing to the detective’s sense of justice and leaving the green-stone idol in her possession—an object she believes capable of revealing the truth.

Following the inquest that returns a verdict of wilful murder by unknown persons, and with Roy committed for trial but reserving his defense, Clara prepares her strategic encounter. The detective visits her as arranged and is soon hidden behind a curtain during a pivotal meeting with Vincent. The ensuing scene is tense and revealing. Vincent, under Clara’s steady interrogation, confesses his love for her despite his marriage, calling his wife “gone” and disparaging his former affection for her. His declarations reveal his desire to marry Clara and his suspicion and condemnation of Roy as the murderer.

Clara confronts Vincent with the green-stone idol, asking pointedly if he believes Roy was the person who left it behind while committing the murder. Vincent feigns ignorance, though the detective notes Vincent’s defiant acknowledgment of meeting a captain of a New Zealand steamer at the Alhambra—a connection that ties back to the idol’s origins and suggests premeditation or at least deeper knowledge than he admits.

This confrontation crystallizes the story’s core tensions: the intersection of hidden passion, jealousy, and financial desperation, played out with the enigmatic green-stone idol as both literal and symbolic evidence. Vincent emerges not as the wronged husband but as a man driven by self-interest and passion, perhaps implicating him more deeply in the murder. Clara’s boldness and clever deductions strain against the limitations of formal detective procedure, providing a humanizing and dramatic counterpoint to the official inquiry.

Throughout the narrative, the detective maintains a balanced, skeptical stance, wary of quick judgments and aware of the flaws in human testimony. The story critiques easy solutions, suggesting that evidence can mislead and that truths often lie beneath emotionally charged facades. The idol’s foreign provenance and mysterious presence in the scene of the crime tie the local tragedy to unexpected cultural and interpersonal complexities.

In summary, “The Green-Stone God and the Stockbroker” is a richly textured detective tale that blends meticulous police work with psychological and social insight. The story probes the fragile boundaries between friendship, love, jealousy, and betrayal, set against a backdrop of financial woes and enigmatic artifacts. The evolving narrative—from Roy’s arrest and defense, Mr. Vincent’s denials and hidden passions, Clara Ford’s courageous advocacy, to the symbolic weight of the green-stone idol—challenges readers to look beyond surface appearances. It reveals a nuanced mosaic where the true murderer’s identity remains shrouded in complexity, highlighting the detective’s cautious reasoning amidst human frailty and the shadows of secret desires.

<THOUGHT PROCESS>
1. MOTIVE
   •  Julian Roy – Needed £200 to save Clara Ford’s brother, but he could have obtained it legitimately with a promissory note or by renewed borrowing.  No gain in murdering Mrs Vincent; in fact, killing her would immediately stop the loan and ensure a police hunt.  No emotional motive.
   •  Paul Vincent – Two converging motives:
        a) Passion: he is in love with Clara Ford and wants his wife “out of the way”.
        b) Self-interest: if Mrs Vincent dies during a supposed burglary, he keeps all his property and can marry Clara – while an easy-to-frame scapegoat (Roy) removes suspicion from himself.
   •  An unknown burglar – would steal jewellery or portable valuables as well, not merely £200 in notes.  No known link with the green-stone idol.

2. OPPORTUNITY
   •  House showed no forcible entry; the murderer was either admitted or held a key.  That fits the husband, not an outsider, and certainly not Roy who was seen to depart peacefully.
   •  Vincent’s “business trip” is self-certified; nothing proves he could not slip back to Brixton, commit the murder, and return to town.
   •  Roy’s known visit ended with Mrs Vincent alive and “quite cheerful” according to two servants who heard them talking but no quarrel.  The timing leaves a gap between Roy’s departure and the moment the body is discovered—ample time for Vincent.
   
3. PHYSICAL / CIRCUMSTANTIAL EVIDENCE
   •  Broken fencing-foil – Mrs Vincent grabbed the first thing at hand, suggesting she recognised the attacker (one does not fence with a stranger holding an axe).
   •  Missing hatchet – an indoor tool; again points to someone familiar with the house.
   •  Green-stone (Maori) idol – clue clinches it.  No one but Vincent is connected with New Zealand, and he admits meeting “a captain of a New Zealand steamer at the Alhambra.”  So the idol was Vincent’s, inadvertently or purposely dropped.  
   •  Stolen notes – Roy is found with them because Mrs Vincent handed them over voluntarily (as Roy says).  The thief/murderer therefore did NOT take the money; the “robbery” is staged.
   •  Vincent’s conduct – speaks of his wife in the past tense (“She is gone”) even before the coroner’s verdict; tries to blacken Roy; is eager to marry Clara at once.  Classic behaviour of a guilty spouse framing a rival.

4. LOGICAL DEDUCTION
   a) If Roy were the killer, he would not leave the idol belonging to Vincent; he would pocket it or throw it away.
   b) If an unknown burglar were the killer, he would not know where the household hatchet was kept, nor restrict himself to £200.
   c) The only person who benefits by both Mrs Vincent’s death and Roy’s arrest is Paul Vincent.
   Therefore Paul Vincent is the murderer, acting alone.  No evidence shows that Clara, the captain, or anyone else helped him.
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

<SUSPECTS>
Paul Vincent, Julian Roy, Clara Ford, Ford’s unnamed brother, An unknown burglar
</SUSPECTS>

<MAIN CULPRIT(S)>
Paul Vincent
</MAIN CULPRIT(S)>

<ACCOMPLICE(S)>
None
</ACCOMPLICE(S)>

<EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>
1. While ostensibly away on business, Paul Vincent slips back to Ulster Lodge with his own key.
2. Earlier, wanting both to placate Roy (and keep him close at hand as a future scapegoat) and to set up an alibi, Vincent told Roy that Mrs Vincent would give him £200 that very night.
3. Roy arrives, receives the notes from Mrs Vincent, thanks her, and leaves at about 9 p.m.
4. Shortly afterwards Vincent enters the study.  His wife is surprised but not alarmed; when he declares he is leaving her for Clara she resists him.  She snatches a fencing-foil from the wall; he seizes the small hatchet from the bookcase.  In the struggle the foil snaps; Vincent strikes repeatedly, killing her.
5. To divert suspicion he up-ends drawers, removes the hatchet, and drops (or places) the Maori green-stone idol near the fireplace, turning the scene into a bizarre “burglar’s job” by some exotic intruder.
6. He slips away, rejoins his “business” route, and telegraphs the police next morning as the bereaved, outraged husband.
7. Because the £200 is missing from the safe and the notes are later found in Roy’s possession, the police seize on the apparent motive and arrest Roy.
8. Clara Ford, convinced of Roy’s innocence, lures Vincent into a private interview.  Under her skilful probing, Vincent admits both his passion for her and his deeper knowledge of the idol—confirming the detective’s suspicions.  He is subsequently charged and convicted of his wife’s murder.
</EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>

<WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
•  Julian Roy – Entered the house openly, received the money openly, left Mrs Vincent alive, and had no practical or emotional gain from killing her.  The only incriminating fact (possession of the notes) is fully explained by Mrs Vincent’s voluntary hand-over, and no physical evidence links him to the violent struggle.
•  Clara Ford – Nowhere near Ulster Lodge that night; her only involvement is exposing Vincent.  No motive to kill a woman who stood between her and Roy’s benefactor.
•  Ford’s brother – Never leaves his lodgings; his entire concern is the embezzlement case against himself.
•  Unknown burglar – No signs of forced entry, minimal loot, and presence of a household hatchet all contradict professional burglary.  Pure red herring planted by Vincent.
</WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>

﻿As a rule, the average detective gets twice the credit he deserves. I am not talking of the novelist’s miracle-monger, but of the flesh and blood reality who is liable to err, and who frequently proves such liability. You can take it as certain that a detective who sets down a clean run and no hitch as entirely due to his astucity, is young in years, and still younger in experience. Older men, who have been bamboozled a hundred times by the craft of criminality, recognize the influence of Chance to make or mar. There you have it! Nine times out of ten, Chance does more in clinching a case than all the dexterity and mother-wit of the man in charge. The exception must be engineered by an infallible apostle. Such a one is unknown to me — out of print.
This opinion, based rather on collective experience than on any one episode, can be substantiated by several incontrovertible facts. In this instance, one will suffice. Therefore, I take the Brixton case to illustrate Chance as a factor in human affairs. Had it not been for that Maori fetish — but such rather ends than begins the story. Therefore it were wise to dismiss it for the moment. Yet that piece of green-stone hanged — a person mentioned hereafter.
When Mr and Mrs Paul Vincent set up housekeeping at Ulster Lodge they were regarded as decided acquisitions to Brixton society. She, pretty and musical; he, smart in looks, moderately well off, and an excellent tennis-player. Their progenitors, his father and her mother (both since deceased), had lived a life of undoubted middle-class respectability. The halo thereof still environed their children, who were, in consequence of such inherited grace and their own individualisms, much sought after by genteel Brixtonians. Moreover, this popular couple were devoted to each other, and even after three years of marriage they posed still as lovers. This was as it should be, and by admiring friends and relations the Vincents were regarded as paragons of matrimonial perfection. Vincent was a stockbroker; therefore he passed most of his time in the City.
Judge, then, of the commotion, when pretty Mrs Vincent was discovered in the study, stabbed to the heart. So aimless a crime were scarce imaginable. She had many friends, no known enemies, yet she came to this tragic end. Closer examination revealed that the escritoire had been broken into, and Mr Vincent declared himself the poorer by two hundred pounds. Primarily, therefore, robbery was the sole object, but, by reason of Mrs Vincent’s interference, the thief had been converted into a murderer.
So excellently had the assassin chosen his time, that such choice argued a close acquaintance with the domestic economy of Ulster Lodge. The husband was detained in town till midnight; the servants (cook and housemaid), on leave to attend wedding festivities, were absent till eleven o’clock. Mrs Vincent, therefore, was absolutely alone in the house for six hours, during which period the crime had been committed. The servants discovered the body of their unfortunate mistress and raised the alarm at once. Later on Vincent arrived to find his wife dead, his house in possession of the police, and the two servants in hysterics. For that night nothing could be done, but at dawn a move was made towards elucidating the mystery. At this point I come into the story.
Instructed at nine o’clock to take charge of the case, by ten I was on the spot noting details and collecting evidence. Beyond removal of the body nothing had been disturbed, and the study was in precisely the same condition as when the crime was discovered. I examined carefully the apartment, and afterwards interrogated the cook, the housemaid, and, lastly, the master of the house. The result gave me slight hope of securing the assassin.
The room (a fair-sized one, looking out on to a lawn between house and road) was furnished in cheap bachelor fashion; an old-fashioned desk placed at right angles to the window, a round table reaching nigh the sill, two arm-chairs, three of the ordinary cane-seated kind, and on the mantelpiece an arrangement of pipes, pistols, boxing-gloves, and foils. One of these latter was missing.
A single glimpse showed how terrible a struggle had taken place before the murderer had overpowered his victim. The tablecloth lay disorderly on the floor, two of the lighter chairs were overturned, and the desk, with several drawers open, was hacked about considerably. No key was in the door-lock which faced the escritoire, and the window-snick was fastened securely.
Further search resulted in the following discoveries:
1.  A hatchet used for chopping wood (found near the desk).
2.  A foil with the button broken off (lying under the table).
3.  A green-stone idol (edged under the fender).
The cook (defiantly courageous by reason of brandy) declared that she had left the house at four o’clock on the previous day and had returned close on eleven. The back door (to her surprise) was open. With the housemaid she went to inform her mistress of this fact, and found the body lying midway between door and fireplace. At once she called in the police. Her master and mistress were a most attached couple, and (so far as she knew) they had no enemies.
Similar evidence was obtained from the housemaid with the additional information that the hatchet belonged to the woodshed. The other rooms were undisturbed.
Poor young Vincent was so broken down by the tragedy that he could hardly answer my questions with calmness. Sympathizing with his natural grief, I interrogated him as delicately as was possible, and I am bound to admit that he replied with remarkable promptitude and clearness.
“What do you know of this unhappy affair?” I asked when we were alone in the drawing-room. He refused to stay in the study, as was surely natural under the circumstances.
“Absolutely nothing,” he replied. “I went to the City yesterday at ten in the morning, and, as I had business to do, I wired my wife I would not return till midnight. She was full of health and spirits when I last saw her, but now —” Incapable of further speech he made a gesture of despair. Then, after a pause, he added, “Have you any theory on the subject?”
“Judging from the wrecked condition of the desk I should say robbery —”
“Robbery?” he interrupted, changing colour. “Yes, that was the motive. I had two hundred pounds locked up in the desk.”
“In gold or notes?”
“The latter. Four fifties. Bank of England.”
“You are sure they are missing?”
“Yes. The drawer in which they were placed is smashed to pieces.”
“Did any one know you had placed two hundred pounds therein?”
“No! Save my wife, and yet — ah!” he said, breaking off abruptly, “that is impossible.”
“What is impossible?”
“I will tell you when I hear your theory.”
“You got that notion out of novels of the shilling sort,” I answered dryly. “Every detective doesn’t theorize on the instant. I haven’t any particular theory that I know of. Whosoever committed this crime must have known your wife was alone in the house and that there was two hundred pounds locked up in that desk. Did you mention these two facts to any one?”
Vincent pulled his moustache in some embarrassment. I guessed by the action that he had been indiscreet.
“I don’t wish to get an innocent person into trouble,” he said at length, “but I did mention it — to a man called Roy.”
“For what reason?”
“It is a bit of a story. I lost two hundred to a friend at cards and drew four fifties to pay him. He went out of town, so I locked up the money in my desk for safety. Last night Roy came to me at the club, much agitated, and asked me to loan him a hundred. Said it meant ruin else. I offered him a cheque, but he wanted cash. I then told him I had left two hundred at home, so at the moment, could not lay my hand on it. He asked if he could not go to Brixton for it, but I said the house was empty, and —”
“But it wasn’t empty,” I interrupted.
“I believed it would be! I knew the servants were going to that wedding, and I thought my wife, instead of spending a lonely evening, would call on some friend.”
“Well, and after you told Roy that the house was empty?”
“He went away, looking awfully cut up, and swore he must have the money at any price. But it is quite impossible he could have anything to do with this.”
“I don’t know. You told him where the money was and that the house was unprotected, as you thought. What was more probable than that he should have come down with the intention of stealing the money? If so, what follows? Entering by the back door, he takes the hatchet from the wood-shed to open the desk. Your wife, hearing a noise, discovers him in the study. In a state of frenzy, he snatches a foil from the mantelpiece and kills her, then decamps with the money. There is your theory, and a mighty bad one — for Roy.”
“You don’t intend to arrest him?” asked Vincent quickly.
“Not on insufficient evidence! If he committed the crime and stole the money it is certain that, sooner or later, he will change the notes. Now, if I had the numbers —”
“Here are the numbers,” said Vincent, producing his pocket-book. “I always take the numbers of such large notes. But surely,” he added as I copied them down — “surely you don’t think Roy guilty?”
